title: Awareness of credit card range needed
text:
View Photo 

Promoting greater awareness of available credit card products and improving the ease of moving from one card to another are options being considered by a Senate inquiry. 
An analysis by comparison website CANSTAR presented to the Senate economics committee on Tuesday found the average credit card interest rate margin over the cash rate has grown from eight per cent in 2007 to 15 per cent in 2015. 
"It's an extraordinary blow out," CANSTAR's Stephen Mickenbecker told the hearing. 
While there had been a bit of a fall in rates on so-called low-interest cards, the escalation had occurred at the top end of the market, he said. 
Tony Pearson, from the Australian Bankers Association earlier explained to the inquiry the increase in the margin was a repricing of risk since the global financial crisis six years ago. 
The trend was also occurring in other countries. 
"There has been the repricing of risk since a very severe shake to global financial markets," Mr Pearson said. 
Labor senator Sam Dastyari, who is chairing the inquiry, argues while mortgage rates have followed the cash rate down, that had not been the case for credit cards. 
"How is that OK?" he asked, while acknowledging the difference between secured debt, such as a home loan, and unsecured debt on credit cards. 
The association says the cash rate is only one component in setting the interest rate. 
There were significant "invisible" costs in providing credit cars, such as fraud and security management and global infrastructure. 
Independent senator Nick Xenophon had one message to the banks: "Pull the other one." 
"They are making record profits on credit cards ... we need reform, we need more competition in the sector," he told reporters in Adelaide. 
Mr Mickenbecker said consumers must be at least on the right card and in some cases avoid the lure of reward schemes. 
The set of customers who habitually don't repay their cards in full every month shouldn't even consider rewards. 
"The interest rate will blow the rewards away," he said. @y7finance on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook Awareness of credit card range needed AAP
